caption: The site is beautiful but this fountain style and this modernity do not really fit into the environment. It is beautiful in itself, but it would have been better if it were located near the Centre Pompidou or the Grande Arche

We especially love how these two quite modern fountains, fit in with the old structures, fountains were originally designed as a source of water for the residents of Paris these days more decorative, this one was created by Pol bury.

Pol Bury's Spherades, moving fountains located in the heart of the Royal Palace, emit a smooth song, a murmur of waves mixed with the clicking of metal and the creaking of clockwork. These orders were established in 1981 by Jack Lang at the François Mitterrand Ministry and were installed in the Cours d'Orléans in 1985 at the Honour's Court or in the colonnades of Buren and the garden, in the Constitutional Council and in the Ministry. the culture. Spherades was refurbished in 2015, and has never fully regained its mobility. Water drips over the shimmering curves of the stainless steel balls. The columns and the garden are reflected in the cold brilliance of steel, moving images and hypnotic poetry. Working with the fluid element, Paul Burri chooses to evoke the subtlety of dynamic moods that leave room for the unexpected.
Very nice to take souvenir photos of your stay in Paris.
Nice place, lot of people are taking selfies here.
Poor fit for the surrounding architecture. A sculpture such as this would be welcome in a modern city such as Rotterdam, but is entirely out of place and an incredible eyesore here.
Great installation for photographers!
Very cool baroque style open garden and plaza. Underground rivers.

Too bad there was this construction halyard which spoiled the photos. And it must be prettier during the day. But it was still very nice.

Less touristy site than the great monuments of Paris, although it is well worth a visit. The fountains next to the patio of the columns and the park make it a good place to walk quietly and sit down and rest.

Artistic installation by Pol Bury (1922-2005) consisting of spheres slightly separated centrally by a half-plane. Made of shiny stainless steel, over which water flows, they reflect the rest of the courtyard colonnade and, further away, the garden: they are still, but at the same time they give lights and moving images to the observer who moves.
Very nice place open to the public and very nice to relax for lunch after going to get a takeaway in the area

The two horizontal fountains with metal balls, slowly moving, by Pol Bury were placed in 1985 in the courtyard of Orleans, around the same time as the columns by Daniel Buren.  Pol Bury, Belgian artist born in 1922 in Wallonia, died in October 2005, he moved to France in 1961. He installed fountains, from the University of Iowa (1969), to the Maeght Foundation (1978) or to the Seoul Games (1988), also designing gigantic works, magnetic drums on which 12,000 ball-balls (1971) or, as at Fiac 1999 (Louis-Carré gallery), a fountain made up of fourteen polished steel spheres.  Pol Bury's two horizontal fountains with slowly moving metal balls were placed in 1985 in the courtyard of Orléans, around the same time as Daniel Buren's columns.  Pol Bury, Belgian artist born in 1922 in Wallonia, died in October 2005, he moved to France in 1961. He installed fountains at the University of Iowa (1969), at the Maeght Foundation (1978) and at the Seoul Games (1988), also designing gigantic works, magnetic drums on which 12,000 marble balls drift ( 1971) or, as at the Fiac 1999 (Louis-Carré gallery), a fountain made up of fourteen polished steel spheres.
Impressive works of art metal spheres which are inside a fountain. Unfortunately at the time we visited the fountain was not working and we did not see exactly how this amazing work of art works.
A very relaxing garden with all these works of art accessible to all which is worth the detour after a visit to the Louvre museum.

These are very pretty modern fountains....unfortunately, the Spherades, these two fountain-sculptures by Pol Bury (1985) are half functional. The water flows over the shiny spheres but it doesn't animate them as it should. Wasn't it a kinetic work?...? The ten spheres of polished stainless steel reflect and multiply the colonnades and the sky, opposing the singing lightness of the water to the cold density of the steel. Missing the uncertainty of the original slow movement. Pol Bury was born in Belgium in 1922 and died in 2005 in Paris. He worked a lot with steel and the movement of water, integrating randomness into his work.
Spherades fountain in Paris
Amazing and magnetic structure in a magical place. To have
Non-standard shape of the fountain and many options for the reality reflected in it.
Ball fountains, Pol Bury (Parvis de la cour d’Orléans, Palais Royal)
